answer_html: \(\displaystyle \bigcup_{n=1}^\infty [\frac{1}{n},n]=(0,\infty)\) And so the infimum of this set is 0, while there isn’t a supremum since the set does not have an upper bound.
answer_latex:
$\displaystyle
\bigcup_{n=1}^\infty [\frac{1}{n},n]=(0,\infty)$ And so the infimum of this set is 0, while there isn't a supremum since
the set does not have an upper bound.
hints_html: The supremum of a set of real numbers is the smallest real number that is larger or equal than any number of the set. Conversely, the infimum of a set is the largest real number that is smaller or equal than any number of the set.
hints_latex:
The \emph{supremum} of a set of real numbers is the smallest real number
that is larger or equal than any number of the set. Conversely, the
\emph{infimum} of a set is the largest real number that is smaller or
equal than any number of the set.
hints_raw: The ''supremum'' of a set of real numbers is the smallest real number that is larger or equal than any number of the set. Conversely, the ''infimum'' of a set is the largest real number that is smaller or equal than any number of the set.
sols_html:
Solution to 1.

The supremum of this set is 5, since it is clearly larger than any number in (-1,5) and no number smaller than 5 could have that property. (If you’re not convinced of this, imagine any number smaller than 5, and call it N then there must exist a number between N and 5 so that N cannot be the supremum).

And for a similar reason, the infimum of this set has to be -1.

Solution to 2.

Here the set that we are looking at is all the rational numbers that are between the square root of 3 and the square root of 7. The supremum and infimum of a set do not have to be members of the set, so our intuition isn’t bad: the supremum has to be the square root of 7 and the infimum the square root of 3.

Solution to 3.

This set is the intersection of closed intervals that grow. At \(n=1\) it is the set [3,4] and then [2.5, 5], so we have

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle [3,4]\cap [2.5,5] \cap[2+\frac{1}{3},6-\frac{2}{3}] \cap [2+\frac{1}{4}, 6-\frac{2}{4}] \cap \ldots = [3,4]\end{aligned}\]

since because we’re taking an intersection of larger and larger interval, only the smaller remains. It is now clear that the supremum of that set is 4 and the infimum 3.

Solution to 4.

Here the sets also are growing in size, but this time we are taking a union. Since 1/n converges to 0, the left side of the interval converges to 0 and clearly the right side of the interval converges to infinity. This means that

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle \bigcup_{n=1}^\infty [\frac{1}{n},n] = (0,\infty)\end{aligned}\]

And so the infimum of this set is 0, while there isn’t a supremum since the set does not have an upper bound.
sols_latex:
\textbf{Solution to 1.}

The supremum of this set is 5, since it is clearly larger than any
number in (-1,5) and no number smaller than 5 could have that property.
(If you're not convinced of this, imagine any number smaller than 5, and
call it \emph{N} then there must exist a number between \emph{N} and 5
so that \emph{N} cannot be the supremum).

And for a similar reason, the infimum of this set has to be -1.

\textbf{Solution to 2.}

Here the set that we are looking at is all the rational numbers that are
between the square root of 3 and the square root of 7. The supremum and
infimum of a set do not have to be members of the set, so our intuition
isn't bad: the supremum has to be the square root of 7 and the infimum
the square root of 3.

\textbf{Solution to 3.}

This set is the intersection of closed intervals that grow. At $n=1$ it
is the set {[}3,4{]} and then {[}2.5, 5{]}, so we have

\begin{align*}
\displaystyle
[3,4]\cap [2.5,5] \cap[2+\frac{1}{3},6-\frac{2}{3}] \cap [2+\frac{1}{4}, 6-\frac{2}{4}] \cap \ldots = [3,4]
\end{align*}

since because we're taking an intersection of larger and larger
interval, only the smaller remains. It is now clear that the supremum of
that set is 4 and the infimum 3.

\textbf{Solution to 4.}

Here the sets also are growing in size, but this time we are taking a
union. Since 1/\emph{n} converges to 0, the left side of the interval
converges to 0 and clearly the right side of the interval converges to
infinity. This means that

\begin{align*}
\displaystyle
\bigcup_{n=1}^\infty [\frac{1}{n},n] = (0,\infty)
\end{align*}

And so the infimum of this set is 0, while there isn't a supremum since
the set does not have an upper bound.
sols_raw:
'''Solution to 1.'''

The supremum of this set is 5, since it is clearly larger than any number in (-1,5) and no number smaller than 5 could have that property. (If you're not convinced of this, imagine any number smaller than 5, and call it ''N'' then there must exist a number between ''N'' and 5 so that ''N'' cannot be the supremum).

And for a similar reason, the infimum of this set has to be -1.

'''Solution to 2.'''

Here the set that we are looking at is all the rational numbers that are between the square root of 3 and the square root of 7. The supremum and infimum of a set do not have to be members of the set, so our intuition isn't bad: the supremum has to be the square root of 7 and the infimum the square root of 3.

'''Solution to 3.'''

This set is the intersection of closed intervals that grow. At <math>n=1</math> it is the set [3,4] and then [2.5, 5], so we have

:<math>\displaystyle
[3,4] \cap [2.5,5] \cap [2+\frac{1}{3},6-\frac{2}{3}] \cap [2+\frac{1}{4}, 6-\frac{2}{4}] \cap \ldots = [3,4]
</math>

since because we're taking an intersection of larger and larger interval, only the smaller remains. It is now clear that the supremum of that set is 4 and the infimum 3.

'''Solution to 4.'''

Here the sets also are growing in size, but this time we are taking a union. Since 1/''n'' converges to 0, the left side of the interval converges to 0 and clearly the right side of the interval converges to infinity. This means that

:<math>\displaystyle
\bigcup_{n=1}^\infty [\frac{1}{n},n] = (0,\infty)
</math>

And so the infimum of this set is 0, while there isn't a supremum since the set does not have an upper bound.
statement_html:
For each of the following subsets of \(\mathbb R\) write its supremum and infimum if they exist. If they do not exist write ``None``. You do not need to prove your answers.

  1. \(\left\{ x\in \mathbb R \text{ s.t. } -1 < x < 5 \right\},\)

  2. \(\left\{ x\in \mathbb Q \text{ s.t. } 3 \leq x^2 \leq 7 \right\},\)

  3. \(\bigcap_{n=1}^\infty \left[2+\frac1{n}, 6-\frac2{n}\right],\)

  4. \(\bigcup_{n=1}^\infty \left[\frac1{n},n\right].\)
statement_latex:
For each of the following subsets of $\mathbb R$ write its supremum and
infimum if they exist. If they do not exist write ``None``. You do not
need to prove your answers.

\begin{enumerate}
\itemsep1pt\parskip0pt\parsep0pt
\item
  $\left\{ x\in \mathbb R \text{ s.t. } -1 < x < 5 \right\},$
\item
  $\left\{ x\in \mathbb Q \text{ s.t. } 3 \leq x^2 \leq 7 \right\},$
\item
  $\bigcap_{n=1}^\infty \left[2+\frac1{n}, 6-\frac2{n}\right],$
\item
  $\bigcup_{n=1}^\infty \left[\frac1{n},n\right].$
\end{enumerate}
statement_raw:
For each of the following subsets of <math>\mathbb R</math> write its supremum and infimum if they exist. If they do not exist write ``None``. You do not need to prove your answers.

# <math>\left\{ x\in \mathbb R \text{ s.t. } -1 < x < 5 \right\}, </math>
# <math>\left\{ x\in \mathbb Q \text{ s.t. } 3 \leq x^2 \leq 7 \right\}, </math>
# <math>\bigcap_{n=1}^\infty \left[2+\frac1{n}, 6-\frac2{n}\right], </math>
# <math> \bigcup_{n=1}^\infty \left[\frac1{n},n\right]. </math>
